Description: Terracotta cooking stove fragment. A pot-support, hand-modelled in the form of a stylized bull’s head, with gouged impressions for the eyes and a single gouging for the mouth/nostrils; a top extension is curved and plain both at the front and back, but no horns are indicated. Applied to the front of the head is a smaller bull’s head, with incurving horns, well-marked eyes and a swelling muzzle with the nostrils shown. At the rear is the scar where the object has come away from the fire-bowl. Micaceous red-brown Nile silt with a brown core. Traces of burning through use. Faint red slip or wash.
Curator's comments: Dated late 3rd century BC (Petrie 1886: 42; Şahin 2001: 119, fig. 110:Na 2). Şahin, M. 2001. Hellenistic braziers in the British Museum: Trade contacts between ancient Mediterranean cities. Anatolian Studies 51: 91-132.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3690)
Şahin 2001 / Hellenistic braziers in the British Museum: Trade contacts between ancient Mediterranean cities (p.119, fig. 110:Na 2)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (LA.08) (Phase 3)
